prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Summarized Context:
Detective Gunshoe is describing what the police found at the crime scene.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain Tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Mia Fey
Description: Maya's older sister and my eternal mentor in life and law. Passed away 2 years ago.
Character 2
Name: Godot
Description: A prosecutor who is shrouded in mystery. He seems to know me somehow.
Character 3
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 4
Name: Maggey Byrde
Description: A waitress at Trés Bien. Was found guilty of murder thanks to the phony me.
Character 5
Name: Jean Armstrong
Description: Trés Bien's owner and chef. A witness in the case who is also into aromatherapy.
Character 6
Name: Glen Elg
Description: The victim. Was a programmer. Maggey had apparently never even seen him before.
Character 7
Name: Victor Kudo
Description: Was in Trés Bien at the time of the incident. Has a thing for waitresses.
Character 8
Name: Lisa Basil
Description: The CEO of Blue Screens, Inc., and Glen Elg's boss. Absolutely not a robot.
Character 9
Name: Violetta → Viola Cadaverini
Description: Possibly part of the staff at Tender Lender? A thoroughly bitter person.
Character 10
Name: Furio Tigre
Description: The head of Tender Lender loan company. Also known as "The Tiger".
Character 11
Name: Bruto Cadaverini
Description: The head of the Cadaverini Family crime syndicate. Seems to live for his granddaughter.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: A present from Maya. It reacts to people who have secrets in their hearts. On loan from Maya. Recovered in the kitchen of Trés Bien.
Evidence 2
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An article from December 5th. Says I was trounced and my client was found guilty.
Evidence 3
Name: Sports Paper
Description: Dates from December 3rd, the day of the incident. On it is a doodle that said 'MC Bomber' with an arrow pointing to '100,000' that was crossed out. 'Ahahahaha' and a laughing face are written next to it. Left by a costumer in Trés Bien on Dec. 3rd. Click here for details. Left by the victim. Doodle is in victim's handwriting. Click here for details.
Evidence 4
Name: Job Listings
Description: Picked up from a bench in Vitamin Square. Thrown away by the old man.
Evidence 5
Name: Lunch Special
Description: Trés Bien lunch special. Costs 20 dollars despite how unbelievably bad it tastes.
Evidence 6
Name: Small Bottle
Description: Found in the kitchen. Shape is different from the others bottles. Contents unknown. The victim's ear medicine. Found covered in unidentified fingerprints in the kitchen. The victim's ear medicine. Covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints.
Evidence 7
Name: Scooter
Description: Ridden by my phony. The wheel guard is all smashed up.
Evidence 8
Name: Jean's Loan Contract
Description: Jean's debt is half a million dollars. The owner of the loan is Tender Lender.
Evidence 9
Name: Victor's Note
Description: "Convicted before, a wicked man or woman, repeat offender -- Victor Kudo"
Evidence 10
Name: Glen's Autopsy Report
Description: Died of potassium cyanide poisoning. Time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM.
Evidence 11
Name: Trés Bien Floor Plans
Description: Blueprints of the crime scene. Click here for details. X = victim's seat.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A photo of the scene taken from near the kitchen. Two dining tables are separated by a folding screen. The one closer to the camera is empty. The other one is where the victim collapse on the table. There is an intact vase on each table. A coffee cup is knocked over and the the table cloth is stained by coffee. Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a kind of scary old man, sir.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 1
Testimony: Poor Maggey had passed out from the shock. It must've been real tough for her.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The victim didn't have any identification on him.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 3
Testimony: But we figured out who he was pretty quick, and then the investigation went smoothly.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 4
Testimony: When Maggey was searched, we found the lottery ticket and the bottle of poison.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 5
Testimony: And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene.
Person: Gumshoe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The task is to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants only one pair, and the answer should be in JSON at the end.

First, I need to go through the testimonies provided by Detective Gumshoe. There are six testimonies here. Let's look at each one and cross-reference with the evidence list.

Testimony 5 says: "And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene." So according to Gumshoe, nothing was missing. But looking at the evidence, maybe there's something that should have been there but wasn't, or something was taken.

Now, looking at Evidence 17: Victim's Prescription Bag. The description says "The bag is empty." The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. So the prescription bag was empty when found. If the victim had medicine from the doctor, maybe the ear medicine (Evidence 6) was in there. Evidence 6 is the small bottle, which is the victim's ear medicine, found in the kitchen. So the prescription bag (Evidence 17) is empty, but the ear medicine was found in the kitchen. So the bag was supposed to have the ear medicine, but it's empty. So that suggests that the ear medicine was taken out, which would mean something was missing from the crime scene (the medicine in the bag). However, Testimony 5 claims nothing was missing. Therefore, the empty prescription bag (Evidence 17) contradicts Testimony 5 because the medicine that should have been in the bag was found elsewhere, implying something was indeed missing (the medicine was moved from the bag to the kitchen). But wait, the testimony says "nothing else missing from the crime scene," but maybe the bag was present but empty, so technically the item (medicine) wasn't missing, just moved. Hmm, maybe another angle.

Looking at Evidence 3: Sports Paper. The doodle is in the victim's handwriting, left by him. The Sports Paper was left by a customer on Dec 3rd. But according to Testimony 2: "The victim didn't have any identification on him." But the Sports Paper (Evidence 3) was left by the victim. So if the victim didn't have ID, but the Sports Paper was his, maybe the police found his identity through other means, but Testimony 3 says "we figured out who he was pretty quick." Wait, maybe the Sports Paper had the victim's handwriting, which helped identify him? But the contradiction here might be between Testimony 2 (no ID) and Evidence 3 (left by victim, so perhaps the Sports Paper was a clue to his identity). But how does that contradict? The testimony says no ID, but maybe the Sports Paper was used to identify him. But Testimony 3 says they figured out who he was quickly, which could be because of the Sports Paper. Not sure if that's a contradiction.

Another angle: Testimony 4 states that when Maggey was searched, they found the lottery ticket and the poison. Evidence 14 is the lottery ticket found on Maggey, and Evidence 16 is the poison in her apron. But Evidence 16 says the poison was found in her apron pocket. However, Evidence 15 (Apron) says it has small pockets but big stains. If the apron pockets are small, could a bottle of potassium cyanide fit? The potassium cyanide is a powdery poison, so maybe in a small container. Not sure if that's a contradiction.

Wait, looking at Testimony 5: "nothing else missing from the crime scene." But Evidence 1 is Maya's Magatama, which was recovered in the kitchen. If the Magatama was on loan from Maya, then it was taken to the kitchen. But Maya is the assistant, so maybe she left it there. That might not relate to the testimony.

Alternatively, Evidence 6: Small Bottle (ear medicine) found in the kitchen with Furio Tigre's fingerprints. The victim's prescription bag (Evidence 17) is empty. So the victim should have had the ear medicine in his bag, but it's found in the kitchen with someone else's fingerprints. Therefore, the medicine was moved from the bag to the kitchen. But according to Testimony 5, nothing was missing from the crime scene. If the medicine was originally in the bag (as per the prescription), then the fact that it's not in the bag anymore (it's in the kitchen) would mean that something was missing from the bag, hence contradicting Testimony 5. Because the crime scene's items (the victim's prescription bag) had the medicine missing, and it was found elsewhere. Therefore, Testimony 5's claim that nothing was missing is contradicted by Evidence 17 (empty bag) and Evidence 6 (medicine found elsewhere). Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 17 and Testimony 5.

Wait, but the user wants one pair: an evidence and a testimony. So Evidence 17 (Victim's Prescription Bag, which is empty) and Testimony 5 (nothing else missing). The contradiction is that the victim's prescription bag was empty, implying the medicine was missing, but the testimony says nothing was missing. Therefore, the empty bag (Evidence 17) contradicts Testimony 5. So the answer should be {"evidence": 17, "testimony":5}.

{"evidence": 17, "testimony": 5}

response:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants only one pair, so I have to look through the provided information and find a direct contradiction.

First, let me go through the testimonies. Testimony 2 from Kudo says that Maggey put some white powder into the victim's coffee. The evidence related to the poison is Evidence 16, which is Potassium Cyanide found in Maggey's apron with her fingerprints. But wait, the Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has both the victim's and Maggey's fingerprints, which might support the testimony. However, maybe there's another angle here.

Looking at the other evidences, Evidence 3 is the Sports Paper with a doodle by the victim. The doodle mentions 'MC Bomber' and '100,000' crossed out, with laughing face. The testimony from Kudo (Testimony 0) says the young man (victim) was reading the sports paper. But the doodle is in the victim's handwriting, which might connect to the MC Bomber disc (Evidence 23) which is a virus program. The victim had a meeting with The Tiger (Evidence 20), who is Furio Tigre. Also, the Small Bottle (Evidence 6) has Furio's fingerprints. 

Wait, the contradiction might be between Testimony 2 (Kudo claims Maggey put white powder) and the actual method of poisoning. The autopsy says potassium cyanide poisoning (Evidence 10). But the Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has the poison. However, if the Small Bottle (Evidence 6) is the victim's ear medicine but has Furio's fingerprints, maybe the poison was administered via the ear medicine? Or perhaps the coffee was poisoned, but the fingerprints on the bottle point to Furio, not Maggey. 

But the main contradiction could be about the presence of Maggey's fingerprints on the Potassium Cyanide (Evidence 16) versus another evidence. Wait, but the testimony says she put the powder in the coffee. But if the Coffee Cup has Maggey's fingerprints, that supports the testimony. Hmm.

Wait, let's look at Testimony 5 and 6 from Kudo. He mentions Maggey had a ribbon and loose apron straps, and when he saw her from the front, nothing caught his interest. But maybe the Crime Photo (Evidence 12) shows that the tables are separated by a folding screen. If Kudo was at a table behind the screen, could he actually see Maggey putting something in the coffee? The Crime Photo shows that the victim's seat is behind a folding screen, so Kudo might not have a clear view. So Testimony 2 (saw Maggey put powder) contradicts the Crime Photo's layout, which might block his view. So Evidence 12 (Crime Photo) contradicts Testimony 2.

Alternatively, maybe the Sports Paper's doodle (Evidence 3) has the victim's handwriting indicating something about the MC Bomber and money. If the victim was meeting The Tiger (Furio) as per Evidence 20, and the MC Bomber is a virus worth millions (Evidence 23), maybe the victim was involved with Furio. The doodle's crossed out 100,000 and laughing face could imply a deal gone wrong. If Kudo's testimony says he saw Maggey put the powder, but the actual poison was in the victim's ear medicine (Evidence 6) with Furio's prints, then there's a contradiction. But how does that directly contradict?

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 2 where Kudo says Maggey put white powder in the coffee. The Potassium Cyanide is a powdery poison (Evidence 16), but the Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has the poison. However, if the victim was poisoned via the coffee, why does the Small Bottle (ear medicine) have Furio's fingerprints? Maybe the actual method was different, but the testimony claims it was the coffee. But I'm not sure that's a direct contradiction.

Wait, the Autopsy Report (Evidence 10) says death by potassium cyanide, which matches the Coffee Cup. The testimony says Maggey added powder to the coffee. The evidence shows her fingerprints on the poison and the cup, which supports the testimony. But maybe there's another angle. The victim's Prescription Bag (Evidence 17) is empty, and the Small Bottle (Evidence 6) is his ear medicine but has Furio's fingerprints. If the ear medicine was replaced with poison, but that's not directly related to Kudo's testimony.

Alternatively, looking at the Sports Paper (Evidence 3) which has a doodle in the victim's handwriting with 'MC Bomber' and '100,000' crossed out. The MC Bomber disc (Evidence 23) is a virus program worth millions. The victim was supposed to meet The Tiger (Furio) on the day (Evidence 20). If the victim was involved in a deal with Furio, maybe the poisoning was related to that, not Maggey. So Kudo's testimony that Maggey did it contradicts the evidence of the victim's dealings with Furio.

But how does that directly contradict? Maybe the Sports Paper's doodle (Evidence 3) shows the victim was planning something with the MC Bomber, which is connected to Furio, implying the murder was related to that deal. Therefore, Kudo's testimony that Maggey did it is contradicted by the evidence pointing to Furio's involvement.

Alternatively, the Lunch Special (Evidence 5) is Trés Bien's special, which Maggey served. But the victim died from the coffee. The testimony says the poison was in the coffee, which matches the evidence, so that's not a contradiction.

Wait, another angle: Testimony 2 states that Maggey "conspicuously" put white powder into the coffee. However, the Crime Photo (Evidence 12) shows that the victim's table was behind a folding screen. If Kudo was at a table closer to the camera (the empty one), then the folding screen would block his view of the victim's table. Therefore, Kudo couldn't have seen Maggey putting anything into the coffee, contradicting his testimony. So Evidence 12 (Crime Photo layout) contradicts Testimony 2 (seeing the act).

Yes, that makes sense. The Crime Photo's description mentions two tables separated by a folding screen. The victim's table is the one farther away. If Kudo was at the table closer to the camera (since his vase broke, as per Testimony 18, which is Victor's Testimony: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry." But Victor Kudo is the one giving Testimony 0-6, so he was at his seat where the vase broke. The Crime Photo's X marks the victim's seat, which is behind the screen. Therefore, Kudo couldn't see the victim's table clearly, so his claim in Testimony 2 that he saw Maggey put powder into the coffee is impossible due to the screen blocking the view. Thus, Evidence 12 (Crime Photo) contradicts Testimony 2.

{"evidence": 12, "testimony": 2}

response:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let me go through the given information step by step.

First, looking at the testimonies. Testimony 3 by Kudo says that the serving girl (probably Maggey) brought over the javaccino. Then Testimony 4 says the victim picked up the cup with his free hand (right hand, since the newspaper was in his right hand according to Testimony 1) and took a sip. 

Now, checking the evidences. The Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has a lip stain on the front and a floral handle to the right. If the victim used his right hand to pick up the cup, the handle would be on the right side. But the floral handle is on the right when facing the cup. Wait, if the handle is on the right side, then when holding it with the right hand, the handle would be on the right. But the lip stain is on the front. Hmm. Wait, maybe the position of the handle and the lip stain's location contradict how the victim held the cup. 

Wait, the testimony says he used his free hand (left hand?) because the newspaper was in his right hand. Wait, Testimony 1 says the victim had a newspaper in his right hand. So when he picked up the cup, he must have used his left hand. But the coffee cup's handle is on the right side. If he used his left hand, he would have to reach across to grab the handle, which is on the right. But the lip stain is on the front. Wait, maybe if the handle is on the right, and he uses his left hand, the way he holds the cup would cause the lip stain to be in a different position. Alternatively, if the handle is on the right, the cup is designed to be held with the right hand. So if he used his left hand, the lip stain's position would not align. That could be a contradiction. 

But how does that relate to the testimonies? The testimony says he picked up the cup with his free hand. Since the right hand was holding the newspaper, the free hand is the left. So he should have used his left hand. But the coffee cup's handle is on the right, which is more natural for the right hand. If he used his left hand, the handle's position would be awkward, possibly leading the lip stain to be on the opposite side. Therefore, the presence of the lip stain on the front (as per Evidence 13) might contradict Testimony 4 about using the left hand. 

Wait, but Evidence 13 says: "Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right." So when facing the cup, the handle is on the right. If you hold the cup with your right hand, your lips would touch the front. If you hold it with your left hand, you'd have to turn the cup, causing the lip stain to be on the opposite side. Therefore, the lip stain's position suggests the cup was held with the right hand, but according to the testimony, the victim used his left (free) hand. That's a contradiction. 

So the testimony (Testimony 4) says he used his free hand (left) to pick up the cup, but the evidence (Coffee Cup, Evidence 13) shows that the handle is on the right, which is more naturally used with the right hand, and the lip stain's position would align with right-handed use. Therefore, this is a contradiction between Testimony 4 and Evidence 13.

Wait, but Testimony 4 is Testimony 4, which is the fourth one. So the pair would be Evidence 13 and Testimony 4. But let me check again. Evidence 13: Coffee Cup has the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. The handle is on the right when facing the cup. The lip stain is on the front. If the victim was holding the cup with his right hand (handle on right), the lip stain would naturally be on the front. But according to Testimony 1, the newspaper was in his right hand, so he had to use his left hand. Therefore, Testimony 4 says he picked up the cup with his free hand (left), but the handle's position and lip stain suggest right-handed use. Therefore, contradiction between Testimony 4 and Evidence 13. 

Yes, that seems like a solid contradiction. So the answer should be Evidence 13 and Testimony 4.

{"evidence": 13, "testimony": 4}

response:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. I need to look through each testimony and see if any of the evidence directly contradicts what's being said.

First, let's look at the testimonies. Testimony 0 is from Kudo, but he's not sure of himself, so maybe not that one. Testimonies 1-4 are also from Kudo. Let's check them one by one.

Testimony 1: Kudo says the victim slumped over after sipping his javaccino. The Coffee Cup (Evidence 13) has cyanide, so that lines up. The autopsy report (Evidence 10) confirms poisoning. So no contradiction here.

Testimony 2: Kudo mentions the vase being knocked over. Evidence 18 (Victor's Testimony) says Victor broke the vase at his seat. Wait, but Testimony 2 says "the clumsy idiot upset the vase" which would be Victor, right? But Victor's own testimony (Evidence 18) says he broke the vase. So maybe that's a match. Wait, but the Crime Photo (Evidence 12) shows intact vases on both tables. Wait, no—looking at the Crime Photo description: "There is an intact vase on each table." But Victor's Testimony says he broke the vase at his seat. That's a contradiction! Because the photo shows intact vases, but Victor says he broke one. So the Crime Photo (12) contradicts Victor's Testimony (18), but Victor's Testimony is Evidence 18, not a testimony here. Wait, the Testimony in question here is from Kudo, Testimony 2 and 3. Wait, Kudo's Testimony 2 says "the clumsy idiot upset the vase. He knocked it right over." Then Testimony 3: "It broke, and the strip of cloth... soaked." So according to Kudo, the vase was broken and the cloth got soaked. But the Crime Photo (Evidence 12) says there's an intact vase on each table. That's a direct contradiction. Because if the vase was broken, the photo should show a broken vase. But the photo shows intact vases. So the evidence (Crime Photo, 12) contradicts Kudo's Testimony 2 and 3. 

Wait, the Crime Photo is Evidence 12. So if Kudo's testimony (Testimony 2 and 3) claims the vase was broken, but the photo shows intact vases, that's a contradiction. Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 12 and Testimony 2 or 3. Let me check the testimony numbers. Testimony 2 is Kudo's statement about the vase being knocked over, and Testimony 3 says it broke and the cloth got soaked. So the Crime Photo (Evidence 12) contradicts Testimony 2 and 3. But the user wants only one pair. Which one? Since Testimony 2 is the act of knocking over, Testimony 3 is the result (broken and soaked). The Crime Photo shows intact vases, so both testimonies are contradicted. But maybe Testimony 3 is the one that directly mentions the broken vase, which the photo contradicts. So the contradiction is between Evidence 12 (Crime Photo showing intact vases) and Testimony 3 (says it broke). 

Therefore, the answer should be {"evidence": 12, "testimony": 3}.
